title: Before 1 October 2019, will Ricardo Rosselló cease to be the governor of Puerto Rico?
preds:
Reports are that official resignation is complete.
https://abcnews.go.com/US/puerto-rico-gov-ricardo-rossellos-resignation-effect-hours/story?id=64731767
He has already committed to resigning.

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/888442 https://edition-m.cnn.com/2019/07/25/us/puerto-rico-crisis-ricardo-rossello-resignation-thursday/index.html "In a video posted Wednesday on Facebook, the governor said he will resign at 5 p.m. ET on August 2."  Leaving a small hedge because the Governor hasn't officially resigned yet.

I assumed he would never leave voluntarily the odds of his impeachment must have been high. Raucous celebrations erupt after Puerto Rico governor steps down. But uncertainty lies ahead
https://edition.cnn.com/2019/07/25/us/puerto-rico-crisis-ricardo-rossello-resignation-thursday/index.html

Rossello's upcoming resignation seems to be an inadequate solution to Puerto Rico's problems.  
Possibly much more to come... From: https://theintercept.com/2019/07/24/puerto-rico-protests-ricardo-rossello-la-junta/
"“What we want to do,” López Varona added, “is to use the energy of the moment to bring forward demands that really move into a Puerto Rico that is for Puerto Ricans,” including protecting public services, auditing the debt, and declaring a state of emergency on gender violence. Within the next several months, it’s also possible that PROMESA board members will need to undergo Senate confirmations, following a ruling that they were appointed incorrectly. López Varona and others hope to leverage support in the diaspora to use any potential hearings to draw attention to the illegitimacy of the board as a whole, not just individual members.
“We are not asking for a better control board,” he tells me. “We are asking for investment in Puerto Rico. What we need is a Marshall Plan that invests money in the island and community-initiated programs that are overseen in Puerto Rico — a real process of self-determination that can help Puerto Rico pave its way to whatever it chooses.”

Legislature reportedly "ready to initiate an impeachment process" against Rosselló: https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/puerto-rico-legislature-begin-impeachment-process-against-gov-ricardo-rossell-n1034046
He has been totally abandoned and facing protests. Rumor is that he is resigning soon.
Yes.  Too many protests for him not to resign.

News reports today that Rosselló is expected to resign shortly: https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/24/us/puerto-rico-crisis-wednesday/index.html https://thehill.com/latino/454449-puerto-rico-governor-expected-to-resign-on-wednesday

2 Local news reports that the Governor will resign by noon on Wednesday...
https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/article233048427.html

He has already said he won't run again, and the protests continue. It's going to be very difficult for him to hang on long. https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2019/07/21/Puerto-Rico-Gov-Ricardo-Rossello-says-he-will-not-run-for-re-election-in-2020/2251563763239/ https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/07/23/puerto-rico-gov-ricardo-rossello-may-not-untouchable/1802908001/?utm_source=feedblitz&utm_medium=FeedBlitzRss&utm_campaign=usatoday-newstopstories

A potential base rate could be US state governors who had to resign. This article mentions 5 since 2008, giving a base rate of 45%:
https://yellowhammernews.com/recent-u-s-governors-resign-disgrace-jbunn/
Not sure whether Puerto Rico's special status would warrant adjusting this base rate up or down, maybe a base rate for Caribbean states' leaders should be mixed in? Don't have time to look into this at the moment, but I adjust up due to the current public pressure on the governor to resign.

7/22/19: Today's developments (ref. links included further below) -- particularly the huge public protest -- increase pressure to resign (sooner vs. later).  FWIW, an impeachment 'advisory' committee (House of Representatives, Puerto Rico) has been formed, though that avenue may be slower to unfold -- if needed. (https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/19/us/puerto-rico-protests-friday/index.html, https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/21/us/puerto-rico-ricardo-rossello-resignation.html). Also (as noted by other forecasters), "senior figures" in the governor's own party have called for him to resign. (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jul/19/puerto-rico-governor-ricardo-rossello-protests) (7/22/19 story links:) https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/nidhiprakash/puerto-rico-protest-rossello-resign https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=trQatZPmULk https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/22/us/puerto-rico-protests-monday/index.html

I think he will be forced to resign as I see an awakening among people akin to "mad as hell and not going to take it anymore." So many lost everything in the hurricane and he revealed that he's laughing in the face of their suffering. He is now the focal point for so much wrong and betting he will lose his job.

Defying Protests, Gov. Ricardo Rosselló of Puerto Rico Says He Will Stay On
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/21/us/puerto-rico-ricardo-rossello-resignation.html New elections are not due till 2020. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Puerto_Rico He won't resign and there is no legal mechanism that can force him out of office. Regardless of public anger.

This just came minutes after I posted my forecast, so I increase it to 85%:
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jul/21/puerto-rico-governor-ricardo-rossello-resigns-protests

"Thousands of protesters demanded the resignation of Puerto Rico’s governor, Ricardo Rosselló. Some threw bottles and fireworks at police, who responded with tear gas and rubber bullets. Mr Rosselló is in trouble after 900 pages of chat-group messages were leaked, in which he apparently referred to a female politician as a “whore” and suggested that the us federal board that oversees Puerto Rico’s awful finances should commit a sex act with itself." The Economist, Politics this week. I loved the "commit a sex act with itself". Impeachment committee forms:
[1] https://edition.cnn.com/2019/07/19/us/puerto-rico-protests-friday/index.html Ricardo Rosselló summons cabinet:
https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/national-international/Embattled-Puerto-Rico-Gov-Ricardo-Rossello-Summons-Cabinet-Amid-Protests-513009761.html Just guessing from some bio from wikipedia, he is the son of a former governor, a scientist (didn't have to work hard to get the job) and relatively new to politics, to the point to make very careless (and stupid) comments in a chat. He cut some heads already [1] but refused to resign. It seems he has also been "amortised" by the democrats, not wanting to have any relation with him.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricardo_Rosselló So, more likely than not, he will leave office, question being when. I'd say 75% chances it will be very quick, maybe in days.

There may be many reasons why he should resign.
There may be many people telling him to resign.  
But he is a politician.  He has worked long and hard for the governorship and letting go of power is not easy for anyone and almost impossible for a politician.
He will be there to the end of his term in 2020.
There is too much pressure, particularly as he becomes part of the Democratic presidential process. Several candidates have called for him to step down now.
Government is corrupt, but he seems ok
With many changes happening in the US government, it will be hard for PR to follow and work effectively to enact the regulations (which probably cause more disgruntlement among the inhabitants).

Protestors ready for another protest tonight, ask for resignation by Sunday.
Short term high forecast until there is a resignation or the situation calms down a little. Three Dem Presidential Candidates call for resignation:
https://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/ny-three-candidates-join-calls-for-puerto-rico-governor-to-resign-20190719-s74dd4rwkbekjfwtwyvhvcw3wu-story.html Governors own party leaders call for resignation:
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jul/19/puerto-rico-governor-ricardo-rossello-protests
It is more likely than not that he will resign based on severity of scandal and his undesirability. PR is facing lots of issues and public will direct their anger onto him.
